results.title: 2022 Oscar Nominations: Full Ballot
results.abstract: See this year’s Oscar nominees and make your picks.

results.title: With His Sci-Fi Android, a Filmmaker Considers What It Means to Be Alive
results.abstract: Kogonada, whose new film is the futuristic A.I. drama “After Yang,” reflects on the nature of his work, and of existence.

multimedia.caption: The filmmaker and video essayist Kogonada in Los Angeles.
multimedia.copyright: Tracy Nguyen for The New York Times

results.title: ‘The Batman’ Review: Who’ll Stop the Wayne?
results.abstract: Robert Pattinson puts on the Batsuit and cats around with Zoë Kravitz in the latest attempt to reimagine the Caped Crusader.

multimedia.caption: Robert Pattinson in “The Batman,” directed by Matt Reeves.
Robert Pattinson in “The Batman,” directed by Matt Reeves.
Robert Pattinson in “The Batman,” directed by Matt Reeves.

results.title: ‘Great Freedom’ and the Long Shadow of an Anti-Gay Law in Germany
results.abstract: A new film traces the many decades it took to abolish Paragraph 175, a measure criminalizing sex between men that was strengthened by the Nazis.

multimedia.caption: Hans (Franz Rogowski) first arrives at the prison in 1945 after being held in a Nazi concentration camp.
Hans (Franz Rogowski) first arrives at the prison in 1945 after being held in a Nazi concentration camp.
Hans (Franz Rogowski) first arrives at the prison in 1945 after being held in a Nazi concentration camp.

results.title: Bong Joon Ho and Ryusuke Hamaguchi on Oscar Surprise ‘Drive My Car’
results.abstract: The Korean filmmaker and the Japanese director have long admired each other. The two explain why Hamaguchi’s best-picture nominee resonates.

multimedia.caption: Ryusuke Hamaguchi, left, and his film “Drive My Car” are up for the same awards that Bong Joon Ho and “Parasite” won.
multimedia.copyright: Eric Gaillard/Reuters (Hamaguchi); Philip Cheung for The New York Times (Bong)

multimedia.caption: Ryusuke Hamaguchi, left, and his film “Drive My Car” are up for the same awards that Bong Joon Ho and “Parasite” won.
multimedia.copyright: Eric Gaillard/Reuters (Hamaguchi); Philip Cheung for The New York Times (Bong)

multimedia.caption: Ryusuke Hamaguchi, left, and his film “Drive My Car” are up for the same awards that Bong Joon Ho and “Parasite” won.
multimedia.copyright: Eric Gaillard/Reuters (Hamaguchi); Philip Cheung for The New York Times (Bong)

results.title: To Boycott Russians, or Not? In Film and Beyond, That’s the Question.
results.abstract: A Russian moviemaker with Ukrainian roots and relatives in Kyiv denounced the war. The Glasgow Film Festival dropped his film anyway.

multimedia.caption: The Glasgow Film Theater during the 2020 Glasgow Film Festival. On Monday, its organizers said two Russian movies would be excluded from the 2022 event.
The Glasgow Film Theater during the 2020 Glasgow Film Festival. On Monday, its organizers said two Russian movies would be excluded from the 2022 event.
The Glasgow Film Theater during the 2020 Glasgow Film Festival. On Monday, its organizers said two Russian movies would be excluded from the 2022 event.

results.title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks feature a ruthless wendigo, a cloistered bloodsucker, a bayou demon, wily jungle spirits and a grinning fiend named Rotcreep.

multimedia.caption: Booboo Stewart in “Those Who Walk Away.”
Booboo Stewart in “Those Who Walk Away.”
Booboo Stewart in “Those Who Walk Away.”

results.title: ‘Fresh’ Review: First Date? Try the Veal.
results.abstract: Daisy Edgar-Jones and Sebastian Stan star in a dazzling (and very funny) cannibal romance from Mimi Cave.

multimedia.caption: Daisy Edgar-Jones in “Fresh.”
Daisy Edgar-Jones in “Fresh.”
Daisy Edgar-Jones in “Fresh.”

results.title: ‘The Batman’ and Matt Reeves: Emerging From the Shadow of Other Caped Crusaders
results.abstract: Amid concurrent versions of the crime-fighter, this director aimed for something personal that would also serve a studio’s needs. The result is a foreboding vision.

multimedia.caption: Matt Reeves became comfortable making large-scale studio movies after realizing “there was a way to do something personal that still had the genre aspect to it.”
multimedia.copyright: Devin Oktar Yalkin for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Matt Reeves became comfortable making large-scale studio movies after realizing “there was a way to do something personal that still had the genre aspect to it.”

results.title: With ‘Lucy and Desi,’ Amy Poehler Gets to the Heart of a Marriage
results.abstract: The performer and director wanted to deliver a down-to-earth portrayal of a couple whose union was far from perfect, even if viewers wouldn’t accept that.

multimedia.caption: Amy Poehler at work on the documentary about the “I Love Lucy” stars.
Amy Poehler at work on the documentary about the “I Love Lucy” stars.
Amy Poehler at work on the documentary about the “I Love Lucy” stars.

results.title: Akaash Singh and His Case for Bringing Back Apu
results.abstract: The stand-up comic, whose special has gone viral, takes issue with how some South Asians like Hari Kondabolu portray their experience in the United States.

multimedia.caption: Akaash Singh calls Apu “the American dream” in his 20-minute debut special, titled (naturally) “Bring Back Apu.”
multimedia.copyright: Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet for The New York Times

results.title: Alan Ladd Jr., Hitmaking Film Executive, Dies at 84
results.abstract: When other studios didn’t want it, he took on the project that became “Star Wars.” He later guided “Chariots of Fire,” “Young Frankenstein” and numerous other movies.

multimedia.caption: The producer and studio executive Alan Ladd Jr. in an undated photo. He often saw potential in filmmakers’ ideas where others did not.
The producer and studio executive Alan Ladd Jr. in an undated photo. He often saw potential in filmmakers’ ideas where others did not.
The producer and studio executive Alan Ladd Jr. in an undated photo. He often saw potential in filmmakers’ ideas where others did not.

results.title: Farrah Forke, Who Played a Helicopter Pilot on ‘Wings,’ Dies at 54
results.abstract: Forke, the namesake of a not-yet-famous family friend named Farrah Fawcett, played Alex Lambert on three seasons of the popular sitcom, a fixture of the NBC schedule in the 1990s.

multimedia.caption: Farrah Forke in 1994 in Beverly Hills, Calif.
multimedia.copyright: Photo by Ron Galella, Ltd./Ron Galella Collection via Getty Images

multimedia.caption: Farrah Forke in 1994 in Beverly Hills, Calif.
multimedia.copyright: Photo by Ron Galella, Ltd./Ron Galella Collection via Getty Images

multimedia.copyright: Photo by Ron Galella, Ltd./Ron Galella Collection via Getty Images

results.title: ‘Great Freedom’ Review: Unbroken
results.abstract: In this moving period drama, a German gay man repeatedly declares his independence in a country that criminalizes his desire and his identity.

multimedia.caption: Only connect: Franz Rogowski in Sebastian Meise’s “Great Freedom.”
Only connect: Franz Rogowski in Sebastian Meise’s “Great Freedom.”
Only connect: Franz Rogowski in Sebastian Meise’s “Great Freedom.”

results.title: ‘Rock Bottom Riser’ Review: A Cosmic View of Hawaii
results.abstract: This experimental documentary takes viewers on a psychedelic tour of Hawaii, exploring the tension between scientific inquiry and Indigenous preservation.

multimedia.caption: A scene from the experimental documentary “Rock Bottom Riser,” directed by Fern Silva.
A scene from the experimental documentary “Rock Bottom Riser,” directed by Fern Silva.
A scene from the experimental documentary “Rock Bottom Riser,” directed by Fern Silva.

results.title: ‘Dear Mr. Brody’ Review: Spreading the Wealth Doesn’t Go Smoothly
results.abstract: The scion of a margarine empire says to ask him for money. And many, many people asked.

multimedia.caption: An offer of money led to many, many requests, by letter. “Dear Mr. Brody” delves into them.
An offer of money led to many, many requests, by letter. “Dear Mr. Brody” delves into them.
An offer of money led to many, many requests, by letter. “Dear Mr. Brody” delves into them.

results.title: ‘Lucy and Desi’ Review: Love in the Time of Television
results.abstract: This documentary, directed by Amy Poehler and about the dynamic duo behind “I Love Lucy,” favors the good times over the difficult ones.

multimedia.caption: Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz are the subjects of the documentary “Lucy and Desi,” directed by Amy Poehler.
Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz are the subjects of the documentary “Lucy and Desi,” directed by Amy Poehler.
Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz are the subjects of the documentary “Lucy and Desi,” directed by Amy Poehler.

results.title: ‘We Are a Film Festival First.’ A Focus on Children Comes Second.
results.abstract: The New York International Children’s Film Festival returns with a diverse, sophisticated slate, including Richard Linklater’s animated take on the 1969 moon landing.
des_facet: New York International Children's Film Festival

multimedia.caption: “Where Is Anne Frank,” directed by Ari Folman (“Waltz With Bashir”), focuses on Kitty, the imaginary friend to whom Anne’s diary was addressed.
“Where Is Anne Frank,” directed by Ari Folman (“Waltz With Bashir”), focuses on Kitty, the imaginary friend to whom Anne’s diary was addressed.

results.title: ‘After Yang’ Review: Do Androids Dream of Sheep, Babysitting, Being?
results.abstract: Colin Farrell plays a father who tries to repair the family’s caretaker-android in a science-fiction tale about what it means to be human.

multimedia.caption: And android makes four: from left, Colin Farrell, Jodie Turner-Smith, Malea Emma Tjandrawidjaja and Justin H. Min in “After Yang.”
And android makes four: from left, Colin Farrell, Jodie Turner-Smith, Malea Emma Tjandrawidjaja and Justin H. Min in “After Yang.”
And android makes four: from left, Colin Farrell, Jodie Turner-Smith, Malea Emma Tjandrawidjaja and Justin H. Min in “After Yang.”

results.title: ‘Nightride’ Review: One Last Job
results.abstract: The movie is indebted to neon-lit crime thrillers set behind the wheel of an outlaw’s automobile, but it fails to deliver the goods.

multimedia.caption: Gerard Jordan and Moe Dunford in “Nightride.”
Gerard Jordan and Moe Dunford in “Nightride.”
Gerard Jordan and Moe Dunford in “Nightride.”

results.title: ‘Huda’s Salon’ Review: The Services Are Not What You’d Expect.
results.abstract: In Hany Abu-Assad’s pulpy thriller, two Palestinian women are trapped between political enemies that are united in their misogyny.

multimedia.caption: From left, Ali Suliman and Manal Awad in “Huda’s Salon,” a film directed by Hany Abu-Assad.
From left, Ali Suliman and Manal Awad in “Huda’s Salon,” a film directed by Hany Abu-Assad.

results.title: ‘Asking for It’ Review: A Few Rude Men
results.abstract: An all-female gang of vigilantes pursue despicable men in this oppressive revenge fantasy.

multimedia.caption: From left, Alexandra Shipp, Vanessa Hudgens and Kiersey Clemons in “Asking for It.”
From left, Alexandra Shipp, Vanessa Hudgens and Kiersey Clemons in “Asking for It.”

results.title: ‘Mother Schmuckers’ Review: Dumber and Dumbest
results.abstract: In this atrocious comedy, two boneheaded brothers search for a lost dog.

Harpo Guit and Maxi Delmelle in “Mother Schmuckers.”
Harpo Guit and Maxi Delmelle in “Mother Schmuckers.”

results.title: ‘The Long Walk’ Review: A Ghostly Future in Laos
results.abstract: This Laotian drama from Mattie Do presents a world where spirits linger on into a future that has been shaped by technology.

multimedia.caption: Noutnapha Soydara and Por Silatsa in “The Long Walk.”
Noutnapha Soydara and Por Silatsa in “The Long Walk.”
Noutnapha Soydara and Por Silatsa in “The Long Walk.”

results.title: French Female Directors Continue Hot Streak at Rendez-Vous Festival
results.abstract: The series returns in-person with an especially strong slate of work by Frenchwomen — fitting, given their run of honors at top festivals.
des_facet: A Tale of Love and Desire (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Vincent Lindon and Juliette Binoche in the series opener, “Fire,” from Claire Denis.
Vincent Lindon and Juliette Binoche in the series opener, “Fire,” from Claire Denis.

results.title: ‘Against the Ice’ Review: Snow Buddies
results.abstract: A hard-core first half is deflated by sleepy melodrama and a formulaic script in this adventure film about the Danish explorer Ejnar Mikkelsen.

multimedia.caption: Nikolaj Coster-Waldau as Ejnar Mikkelsen and Joe Cole as Iver Iversen in “Against the Ice.”
Nikolaj Coster-Waldau as Ejnar Mikkelsen and Joe Cole as Iver Iversen in “Against the Ice.”

results.title: ‘Hell Is Empty’ Review: Sins of the Father
results.abstract: In this bare-bones horror film, a young woman joins a cult and eventually defies its patriarch.

multimedia.caption: From left, Aya, Laura Resinger, Travis Mitchell, Spencer Peppet and Nia Farrell in “Hell Is Empty.”
From left, Aya, Laura Resinger, Travis Mitchell, Spencer Peppet and Nia Farrell in “Hell Is Empty.”

results.title: Broadway’s Cort Theater Will Have a New Name: James Earl Jones
results.abstract: The landmark theater will be renamed in honor of the 91-year-old actor who has made 21 Broadway appearances and won two competitive Tony Awards.

multimedia.caption: James Earl Jones accepting a special Tony Award for lifetime achievement in 2017.
James Earl Jones accepting a special Tony Award for lifetime achievement in 2017.
James Earl Jones accepting a special Tony Award for lifetime achievement in 2017.

results.title: Ned Eisenberg, New York Actor Known for ‘Law & Order,’ Dies at 65
results.abstract: Eisenberg performed in several Broadway productions between appearances as the defense lawyer Roger Kressler on NBC’s long-running police drama “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.”
des_facet: Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: Ned Eisenberg as Roger Kressler in “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.”
Ned Eisenberg as Roger Kressler in “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.”
Ned Eisenberg as Roger Kressler in “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.”

results.title: ‘The Unknown Man of Shandigor’ Review: A Sci-Fi Fable of the Nuclear Anxiety Age
results.abstract: What if you had a formula to sterilize all the world’s nuclear weapons? This newly restored 1967 spy spoof suggests you’d be much sought-after.

multimedia.caption: Daniel Emilfork in “The Unknown Man of Shandigor.”
Daniel Emilfork in “The Unknown Man of Shandigor.”
Daniel Emilfork in “The Unknown Man of Shandigor.”

results.title: ‘Summer of Soul’ Reclaims a Concert Documentary Tradition
results.abstract: As music stars turn to movies as promotional tools, the Questlove project looks back to a golden age of filmed performances that the academy rarely acknowledges.
des_facet: Summer of Soul (... Or, When the Revolution Could Not Be Televised) (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Sly Stone in a scene from “Summer of Soul,” about the 1969 Harlem Cultural Festival.

results.title: Gérard Depardieu, Friend of Putin, Denounces ‘Fratricidal War’
results.abstract: “Stop the weapons and negotiate,” the French actor and staunch Russia ally told a news agency.

results.abstract: This documentary looks back at a Cold War defection drama that took place off the coast of Massachusetts.

results.title: Watch These 13 Movies Before They Leave Netflix in March
results.abstract: It’s awards season, and a bunch of great Oscar-winning and -nominated films are leaving this month. Check them out while you can.
